goals__remit:
For the next four years (2015-2019), the UNESCO Chair will continue to contribute to identifying and sustaining actions needed for the strengthening of HE-graduate employment/employers links in Romania, the increased assurance of the quality of learning and competencies provided by higher education in the country, the provision of skills for lifelong learning as well as the improvement of the employability rate among graduates.  
The mission of the UNESCO Chair is geared towards better serving not only the needs of graduates but also the needs of the wider regional community for more diversified learning programs, adult education and continuing professional education programs that have emerged along with the new labour market demands and different job profiles, in an attempt to fill the gaps of education for the unemployed, under-represented and excluded groups. Under the broad perspective of lifelong learning, the Chair aims to serve the entire country and region by making a relevant contributions in the LLL fields of competence, and to link its activities not only with those of national academic communities, universities, and research institutes towards a better intra-national/regional mobilization of learners, but also with those of the lifelong learning communities of other UNITWIN Chairs in the wider UN system.  
Under this vision, the UNESCO Chair aims to increase and diversify the range of lifelong learning activities, from socially static to more relational, evolutionary, and more compatible with the region’s territorial approaches.   
 
Objectives 
Development objective (long term)  
 
The primary objective of the UNESCO Chair’s activities shall be to build human and social capital in Romanian (higher) education so as to meet the major global, national and regional needs of development of market economy and democratic participation, with special focus on Romania and South East Europe.  
 
Specific objectives 
 
•    To develop research on LLL, quality of HE, QA, quality culture, etc 
•    To provide skills for lifelong learning and professional development through provision of re-skilling modules, courses, programmes for our own university’s graduates, as well as graduates from other institutions and non-traditional, underrepresented, marginalized student groups 
•    To create a dynamic, ongoing researchers’ forum where  innovative policy and best practices will inform  each other
